query: SELECT DISTINCT observations.id FROM `observations` ORDER BY observations.id ASC

results.notes: Looks like a clumped black “knot” on the branch of a young tree that wraps around its branch. Several similar lumps on other branches. Inside is a slightly lighter brown, almost woody-looking dust. In a wooded area with several other young trees.
results.location_name: Frautschi Point, UW-Madison Lakeshore Nature Preserve, Madison, Wisconsin, USA

results.notes: Blue-ish gray-ish foliose lichen found on a dead log heavy with moss. The bottom of the lichen is dark, almost black, and it doesn’t peel off easily. Has a darker, brownish stain on the top. Only a few centimeters wide and across.
results.location_name: Bill's Woods, UW-Madison Lakeshore Nature Preserve, Madison, Wisconsin, USA

results.notes: Found on lower bark of tree along path in shaded area. Location of lichen is Bill’s Woods (mixed deciduous woodland). Color is lemon-yellow to yellow-green. KOH (1M) test turned lichen deep red, indicating genus is Xanthomendoza (vs. look alike Candelaria).
results.location_name: Bill's Woods, UW-Madison Lakeshore Nature Preserve, Madison, Wisconsin, USA

notes_fields.Location: Bills Woods, UW Madison Lakeshore Nature Preserve
notes_fields.Substrate: This was found growing on a large log, some of the same species present on the same log. Some were growing on top of each other in small clusters (no more than 3/4 were found growing close together).
notes_fields.Habitat: The cap was about 7cm wide, but some found were slightly larger or smaller in size. The cap was darkest in the middle, almost black, and the edges are slightly lighter brown. Stem was present and growing straight out of the wood, it was darker than the underside of the cap. The area is common to conifers and hardwoods.

results.notes: There was a collection of these on a rotting log on the ground. The top was brown and black. There was a little stem at the bottom that was attached to the tree. It was dry and brittle. The bottom was white/brown with pores.
results.location_name: Bill's Woods, UW-Madison Lakeshore Nature Preserve, Madison, Wisconsin, USA

notes_fields.Location: Bills Woods, UW Madison Lakeshore Nature Preserve
notes_fields.Substrate: This was found growing out of the ground surrounded by fallen leaves. The area was damp.
notes_fields.Habitat: It was found near some new plant growth and after recent rainfall. The area is common to oak and other hardwood trees that have recently fallen, some of these trees were found decaying in the area. The ascocarp is about 2cm wide and darkly colored and has a flaky brown layer to it.

results.notes: This was found around 2 other of the same species. It was black and brittle. Found among fallen leaves and there were many decaying logs surrounding the area. The stem is a little lighter than the cap.
results.location_name: Bill's Woods, UW-Madison Lakeshore Nature Preserve, Madison, Wisconsin, USA

results.notes: This was found along a dead piece of wood. Slightly orange in color and browner in the middle/bottom. There was a lot of decaying wood around. The pores were also pretty distinct and it looked almost hairy.
results.location_name: Bill's Woods, UW-Madison Lakeshore Nature Preserve, Madison, Wisconsin, USA

results.notes: This looked like some sort of shelf fungi. It is white on the top and slightly more yellow on the underside. It has a small stem. Was found on a decaying log with a collection of similar looking fungi.

notes_fields.Location: Bills Woods, UW Madison Lakeshore Nature Preserve
notes_fields.Substrate: This lichen was found on a fallen branch that was decaying. It was fairly dry. This area is deciduous and has many hardwood trees.
notes_fields.Habitat: Apothecium are observed, they are slightly more orange in color than the lichen itself, which is more yellow. It has a foliose-looking growth. The spot it covered was about 1cm wide and the apothecium were about 1mm wide. There are other lichen growing on the same branch, with most of it growing in isolation from the other growths. There are a handful of apothecium growing on top of another lichen.

results.notes: This is some sort of brightly colored lichen, it is green and has orange cup-like features on it. It grew in patches on a fallen branch surrounded by decaying logs.

results.notes: This mushroom was found alone, it was near other mushrooms that were slightly different. It was found in a pile of decaying logs. It was very small and brown all around. The cap was flattened and the gills were very large and far apart from each other. It was a dark orange/brown color all over (including stem, but was slightly darker). It was about 2.5cm long with a flatter cap. An indent was present in the middle of the cap and the edges were rough/uneven.

It had rained recently so the area was very damp. The cap is about 1cm wide.

results.notes:
Habitat: found in adjacent garden beds fertilized with Black Kow manure, into which the cups are shallowly rooted.
Cup: 1.5-4.0 cm in diameter. Slow to develop and mature (10 days or more), consistently cup-shaped with an incurved margin, often laterally flattened like a coin purse.
Fertile surface usually smooth but can be wrinkled or dotted with clumps strongly resembling the exterior surface.
Exterior surface warty, not haired.
Stalk rudimentary above a short, whitened “root.”
Odor strongly of morels.

notes_fields.Substrate: Found on a thin, fallen deciduous log in an early stage of decay.
notes_fields.Setting: Habitat was mostly deciduous stand of trees in a mixed forest setting. Log was sitting on bed of deciduous leaves about ten feet away from a steep ledge.
notes_fields.Morphology: Four fruiting bodies dispersed across log in various stages of growth.  Fungus was fairly hard, and fracture-like cracks had begun to form on top of fruiting body. Growth-ring type coloration also characterized the top of the cap. No stem/stipe present. Bottom side was white with dots of brown throughout, and also streaked brown when scratched.

results.location_name: Bill's Woods, UW-Madison Lakeshore Nature Preserve, Madison, Wisconsin, USA

notes_fields.Substrate: Found growing out of soil under clutter of deciduous leaves and detritus.
notes_fields.Setting: Habitat was mixed deciduous-coniferous forest, specifically underneath a few coniferous trees. Multiple fallen logs were in area surrounding the leaf litter specimen was growing out of. Set far off main trail, without much evidence of human disturbance.
notes_fields.Morphology: Two stipes with apothecia could be seen growing next to each other, and they appeared to be isolated, although one appeared to have been eaten, so there could have been more previously. Outside of apothecia was black with brown spots that formed an almost bumpy texture. The inside of the the apothecia appeared to be a dark brown on the walls and black at the bottom.

results.location_name: Bill's Woods, UW-Madison Lakeshore Nature Preserve, Madison, Wisconsin, USA

notes_fields.Substrate: Growing directly on bark. Tree specimen was found on was large deciduous tree that had apparently recently fallen, as it was fallen to the ground but still appeared in good conditions and at very early stage of decay.
notes_fields.Setting: Found in deciduous stand of mixed forest near a large lake. There was a abnormally large number of fallen trees in the immediate area surrounding the tree this specimen was on. Appeared to be growing alongside another species of foliose lichen, light blue in appearance.
notes_fields.Morphology: Foliose lichen. Smaller parts of thallus appeared a greenish yellow, while the larger, “flower-looking” structures were more of an orangish-yellow. Some parts of thallus had begun to brown, perhaps where apothecia had opened.

results.notes:
Large group on side and underside of large well-rotted hardwood log in red oak, sugar maple, basswood forest. It is unclear to me, after so many years, if the white fuzzy stuff is mold, but looking now, I rather suspect so. It is also present to a lesser extent in my only other observation. Unfortunately no spore print was attempted.
Note also the interspersed very small white cup fungi.
results.location_name: Wolsfeld Woods Scientific and Natural Area, Hennepin Co., Minnesota, USA

results.notes:
This specimen was found on a freshly broken (but standing) tree in Bill’s Woods in Madison, WI. Just a few feet from the paved Lakeshore nature trail.
The surrounding forest floor was leaf-filled and a little wet from recent rains. Unfortunately, I was unable to identify the species of tree in the image.
The genus (Flavopunctelia) was first identifiable due to the color of the upper cortex of the lichen and the u-shaped lobes. The species was then further identified due to the presence of reproductive soredia on the lichen. In the future, I will make sure to obtain an image that captures the lower cortex in greater detail.
These photos were taken on a cool 45 degree day (fahrenheit).
results.location_name: Bill's Woods, UW-Madison Lakeshore Nature Preserve, Madison, Wisconsin, USA
Clermont Co., Ohio, USA

results.notes:
This specimen was found growing on a pile of decomposing logs (saprotrophic) in Bill’s Woods, Madison WI. The surrounding forest floor was dry and leafy and the photos were taken on a moderately warm 50 degree day (fahrenheit).
The ball-shaped fruiting bodies were just a couple centimeters in width and brownish-black in color.
Importantly, the concentric rings found in the cross sectional picture of a fruiting body was the key determining factor in identifying this species.
The consistency of these fruiting bodies was very dry, tough, and brittle.
The fruiting bodies were quite abundant across many of the wood logs.
I could not identify what tree species the logs belonged to.
results.location_name: Bill's Woods, UW-Madison Lakeshore Nature Preserve, Madison, Wisconsin, USA

Setting: Found off a protected trail. The surrounding trees are mostly oak and elm, though there is a patch of conifers nearby.
Substrate: Superficially looks like it is growing in the soil, but it feels like it is attached to a tree root or a sturdy piece of wood. The understory is mostly oak and elm leaves.

results.notes:
Substrate:Fallen deciduous tree
Morphology Cluster of ascocarps that vary in size and shape. The cross-section of the ascocarp has a slight fan shape. The outer shell of the ascocarp is hard and dry. To reveal the inside of the ascocarp, it had to be carefully sliced open, otherwise, it crumbled. The inside of the ascocarp has perithecia arranged linearly. The defined concentric rings within the ascocarp give the inside of the sporocarp a woody appearance.

results.notes: Wet dead log in Eucalyptus rain forest. Young specimens are Light Brown with smooth body, and as they mature become brown. Spore also brown. I have had several suggestions on this specimen. This image is about 1 week later of a similar or the same specimen shown in MO Obs: (450897). When I removed one of these specimens the outer case was not hard , but could be easily depressed. The last image uploaded is a bisection displayed the following week from the same log area all other images were recorded from. I have only recorded these fungi in this one spot in the National Park. The bottom image shows the woody base and the same light brown spore can be observed in the mid cut section.

notes_fields.Habitat: I spotted this jelly fungus in Caretakers Woods (disturbed mesic hardwood woodland) attached to the side of a fallen hardwood log, possibly an elder as Auricularia fungi are known to colonize this species of tree. Young maple trees were sprouting up all around this observation site and the wood was rather moist, sitting close to the forest floor, but slightly suspended. This individual was growing gregariously with other members of the same species. All of which ranged in size.
notes_fields.Substrate: The fallen, hardwood log was sloughing off most of its bark, and the fungus seemed to favor these areas with the vascular system exposed. The wooden substrate was moist and in an area receiving little direct light due to the overstory.
notes_fields.Location: I found this fungus in Caretakers Woods.

results.notes: The basidiocarp of this fungus was cup-shaped and measured about 2.5 cm across. The hymenium displayed a deep maroon hue with subtle wrinkles. The sterile surface was covered in fine white hairs and appressed to the wood at single points of attachment. The entire body was sclerotized and dried out, suggesting the age of the fungus.
results.location_name: Caretaker's Woods, UW-Madison Lakeshore Nature Preserve, Madison, Wisconsin, USA

notes_fields.Habitat: This slime mold was spotted on a fallen hardwood log at the edge of Caretakers Woods adjacent to the Old Apple Orchard. Caretakers Woods is a mesic woodland, hosting species of hardwood, deciduous trees, including oak, maple, cherry, and hickory. Slime molds prefer moist environments which can be provided by mesic forest ecosystems. This particular location was strewn with decaying, woody debris, likely from recent forest restoration projects.
notes_fields.Substrate: The fallen, hardwood timber had moist wood sloughing off its surface. I found the plasmodium just below the outer layer of some of the decaying bark. No other fungi or fungal-like organisms were present in the direct vicinity of this thallus.
notes_fields.Location: I found this slime mold in Caretakers Woods.

results.notes: The rusty orange plasmodium circumscribed spent sessile, sporangiate fruiting bodies, giving this creature its distinctive diminutive, "wasp nest slime mold. Remnants of capillitia could also be seen in the peridium cups. The overall body of this slime mold measured around cm in size.
results.location_name: Caretaker's Woods, UW-Madison Lakeshore Nature Preserve, Madison, Wisconsin, USA

results.location_name: Franklin Parker Preserve, Woodland Twp., New Jersey, USA

notes_fields.Habitat: Caretakers Woods is a mesic woodland comprising mainly north-facing slopes, which create a moist, cool microclimate within the Lakeshore Nature Preserve. The soil generally holds more water, which can host a variety of organisms unique to this stretch of lakeshore. This disturbed, hardwood woodland habitat is in flux and many old-growth trees are giving way to mesic species. Red oaks predominate in the upper canopy, whereas maples, elms, and cherries are pervasive in the lower canopy. A patch of young maples was sprouting up near this collection site.
notes_fields.Substrate: This fungus was growing gregariously with other members of the same species on a hardwood log. The log was elevated, resting on another nearby fallen tree trunk. Due to its suspended nature, the log was relatively dry and exposed to the elements.
notes_fields.Location: This fungus was spotted in Caretakers Woods of the Lakeshore Nature Preserve.

results.notes: The charcoal-black/dark-brown stromata displayed characteristic concentric rings with a layer of perithecia lining the surface. The fruiting bodies ranged in size from 1 cm to 1.5 cm. The stromal bodies were attached to the wood at single points of attachment. They had no odor and were rather hard and sclerotized. Once sectioned, the interior of the fruiting bodies were friable and fell apart easily.
results.location_name: Caretaker's Woods, UW-Madison Lakeshore Nature Preserve, Madison, Wisconsin, USA

results.notes:
Habitat: Moderately inclined mountain ravine, southeast aspect; rocks and scree with sparse vegetation; calcareous, colluvial ground; full sun, dry place; exposed to direct precipitations; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 6-8 deg C, elevations 680 m (2.250 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: calcareous rocks.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, right bank of river Soa; between villages Soa and Trenta; Skokar’s ravine; upstream from the trail from Trenta 2b to Strgulc abandoned farm house, Soa 47, East Julian Alps, Posoje, Slovenia EC.

Comment: Sarcogyne regularis lichen, which is quite variable, grows on calcareous rocks. It has multi-spore asci, which contain more than 100 spores each. The species is almost impossible to be distinguished from very similar Clauzadea monticola in the field. But the latter has 8-spored asci, which separates both species immediately. Calcareous rock in Trenta (limestone or dolomite) has on some rare places inclusions of much harder rock than surrounding. The intrusions look crystalline and in parts almost as quartz and are colored yellowish-ochre or reddish. But, HCL test proved they were also calcareous. Lecidea type apothecia were strictly limited to these inclusions. The apothecia are black and flat or slightly concave when dry and dark reddish-brown, like somewhat translucent, and distinctly convex. Thallus is immerged in the rock (endolithic) and practically invisible.

Camera: Nikon D700 / Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8

notes_fields.Habitat: I found this fungus in a clearing of Bills Woods (mixed deciduous forest) of the Lakeshore Nature Preserve. The slope was west-facing and littered with duff and woody debris. Without a thick overstory, lots of direct sunlight reached the forest floor. Young hardwood saplings were starting to sprout near this fungus and the fallen log resting nearby.
notes_fields.Substrate: This fungus appeared to originate from somewhere beneath the thick layer of duff on what I would assume to be a portion of hardwood material, like a stick or log. The ground was moist, yet received lots of direct sunlight.
notes_fields.Location: I found this fungus in Bills Woods.

results.notes: The black/brown apothecial cup measured about 4.5 to 5.0 cm across. A rudimentary pseudostem fixed the ascocarp firmly to the duff material below. The outer margin of the apothecium was beginning to curl and crack, indicating its maturity.

results.notes:
This specimen was found in Bill’s Woods, Madison, WI on a cool 45 degree day (fahrenheit) on a section of the leafy forest floor. The substrate is either terrestrial or a buried log (saprobic).
The fruiting body is about 2-3 cm in diameter and 6-7 cm tall. The apothecial fruiting body is dark brown and shaped like a very deep cup/globlet, with an attached stem portion at the base.
Next to the intact specimen is a possibly bitten Urnula that better showcases the length of the stem.
The fertile inside of the fruiting body appears to be a brownish gray with a smoother surface.
The opening of the fruiting body is a bit smaller – perhaps indicating that it is a bit younger in age (which is consistent with it being early season).
results.location_name: Bill's Woods, UW-Madison Lakeshore Nature Preserve, Madison, Wisconsin, USA

results.notes: Cup-shaped apothecium. Growing on decaying wood in mixed deciduous woodland (Bill’s Woods). Habitat is shady. Other U. craterium ascocarps were found within 2 meter circle of this specimen. Inside surface of apothecium is dark brown and smooth. Outside surface of apothecium is grey-brown, rough, and somewhat spotted (spots are medium brown). Ascocarp appears to be growing directly out of decaying log (no visible stipe).

results.notes:
This crustose specimen was found growing on a fallen tree (likely an Oak substrate) in Bill’s Woods, Madison WI (saprobic). The tile-like fruiting bodies are white on the exterior surface and brownish/black on the fleshy interior.
Most of the polygons are less than 0.5 cm in diameter but combined, the network of fruiting bodies takes up over 10×15cm of space on the log.
The surrounding forest floor was very dry and leafy and shaded by many tall oaks and conifers.
This photo was taken on a warm, nearly 70 degree day (fahrenheit).

results.notes:
This orange/red slime mold was found on a decomposing wood log in Caretaker’s Woods, Madison WI (saprobic).
The wood is significantly decayed and crumbling in some parts. I am unsure of the species of tree the branch originates from.
The slime mold fruiting bodies are round and orange in color. The balls are mere fractions of a centimeter in diameter. However, the cluster spans across many centimeters of space.
The surrounding forest floor was dry and leafy, shaded by tall trees. These pictures were taken on a cool 45 degree day (fahrenheit).

I was unable to identify this slime mold at the moment – hopefully I will be able to soon. Any ideas are appreciated.

results.notes:
Growing in a urban irrigated grass area.
- Pileus (1,3 to 2,5 cm diameter, 0,7 to 1,5 cm height). Campanulated to plano-convex, with a slight wide umbo (in older speciments can be depressed),
hygrophanus, translucent striate when moist. Margin slightly excedent. Cuticule can present cracks and fractures. Color chesnut brown when moist and fading to creamy white once dried, the center is more colored than the rest of the pileus.
- Gills adnated, light brown when young and dark brown at maturation, slightly motted, with white edge. Spore print dark chocolate brown.
- Stipe (4 to 6 cm height and 0,15 to 0,3 cm wide). Tubular, lined all along the stipe, finelly purinose at the apex, with white mycelium at the base. Color creamy white, tourning to brown if damaged.
No bruising blue reaction observed.
results.location_name: Crdoba, Spain

No bruising blue reaction observed.

results.notes: I was certain from the looks that this would be a foul smelling fellow, so I was surprised when I held it to my nose and smelled nothing. So I cracked the cap and went in again. This was the worst smelling mushroom I’ve found so far. I expected something fishy or pungently “spermatic” but was met with the smell of a food court dumpster combined with burnt electronics. Basically what I imagine a literal dumpster fire to smell like. I did not give it a taste. Found growing in the grass inches from a sidewalk with an oak being the only nearby tree.

results.notes:
Initially these were collected and photographed by Krista Willmorth.
Growing on rabbit dung and straws.
I think this is subsection Lanatuli, and, it keys out as Coprinopsis radiata or Coprinopsis macrocephala.
Spores smooth, elliptical to oblong, germ pore visible, (13.3-13.9) x (7.8-8.5) aver. L=13.6; aver. W=8.00; Q=1.6. The basidia is (21-25) x (11-12); the pleurocystidia 80×34. The cheilocystidia (27-28) x (10-11) x (4-6). Because the pileus size and the large length of the veil links, I am leaning towards Coprinopsis macrocephala.

results.notes:
On a rotting hardwood log in an Eastern hemlock-dominated mixed forest stand.
A Blast search of GenBank revealed multiple sequences that were identified by the depositers as G. penetrans or G. hybridus with >99% similarity to this collection, although there were sequences identified as G. penetrans with as little as 95% similarity to this sequence, suggesting that species concepts are unclear. Hesler (1969) Mycol. Memoir #3 reserved the name G. hybridus for a European species and did not see NA material that he would refer to this species. Some authors (e.g. Holec J. 2005) consider G. hybridus a synonym of G. penetrans (which seems supported by the Blast results) but others advocate keeping G. hybridus, G. penetrans and G. sapineus as separate species. More work needs to be done.

—

I took a profile of the sporangiophores with a macro-lens, and their stalks are yellow-tan in color. Some of the sporangia are burst open and look like they may contain a black spore mass.

results.notes:
This slime mold was found on the underside of a fallen tree in Bill’s Woods, Madison WI. Unfortunately, I was unable to identify the species of tree.
The surrounding environment was leafy and a bit wet. The forest canopy shaded the area quite well.
This particular yellow/orange slime mold was observed all over the tree and was commonly hidden by a layer of decaying moist bark. In the second image, goblet shaped structures are visible (burst) in the top left as well as some short stems in other images.
The cluster photographed here is about 2.5 × 1 cm in area.
I am unsure of what genus or species this might be.

These photos were taken on a warm 60 degree day (fahrenheit) and it is worth noting that the forest has bloomed substantially since last week’s observations.

results.notes:
Orange rust fungi growing on mayapple. Orange teliospores are visible on underside of plant leaf. Some orange discoloration is also visible on the upper surface of plant leaf.

results.notes:
On the riparian side of the Boise river (Idaho, USA) under cottonwoods with sandy soil.
Veil some shade of white, soon disappearing, microscopically a layer of globose cells.
Stipe relatively smooth, couldnt find caulocystidia.
Spores smooth, flattened, not mitriform (except a questionable few), ends rounded with a gem pore about 1.5 . Here providing two dimensions on the width: (8 9) x (6-6.3) x (5-5.6); aver. 8.48 X 6.13 X 5.23; Aver Q_F=1.38; Aver Q_S= 1.57.
I think is Coprinellus saccharinus because the veil is white, the spores are broader, and they are a few submitriform spores in the mix.
Other mic. data:
Velar cells (40-56); Basidia (20-27) x (8-9); Sterigmata 2.5-3.5; cheilocysyidia ( 44-76) x (26-56); pleurocystidia 73-38; additional spores dim in the spore chart.

results.notes: Fungi growing on decaying wood. Found in shaded region of mixed deciduous woodland (Bill’s Woods). Mushroom is woody in texture. Intricate, maze-like pore surface on underside of basidiocarp. No stipe is present. Color is light grey on top surface; slightly lighter on underside. Some speckling of darker colors is present on mushroom (may be other fungi growing on this basidiocarp).
results.location_name: Bill's Woods, UW-Madison Lakeshore Nature Preserve, Madison, Wisconsin, USA

notes_fields.Habitat: I found this rust fungus in Bills Woods (a mixed deciduous forest). The particular slope was rather dry with patches of direct sun streaming through the budding canopy. Mayapples littered the forest floor with their distinctive umbrella-like foliage. Young maple trees were sprouting up around this patch and many hardwood, fallen logs crisscrossed the forest floor, providing ample material for saprobic species of fungi common to these woods.
notes_fields.Substrate: This fungus was growing at the margins of abaxial leaf surfaces on a patch of mayapple ephemerals. The leaves were succulent and glossy, suggesting recent leafing-out events. No mayapple flowers or fruits had developed yet.
notes_fields.Location: This fungus was observed in Bills Woods of the Lakeshore Nature Preserve.

results.notes: This distinctive rust fungus boasted brilliant, orange aecial cups ranging in size from mm to 1 mm across. The clusters of cup-like aecia were larger ranging in size from 1 cm to 2 cm across. Due to its pathogenic presence, the fungus altered the visual appearance of the adaxial leaf surface, giving the leaves tell-tale signs of chlorosis.
results.location_name: Bill's Woods, UW-Madison Lakeshore Nature Preserve, Madison, Wisconsin, USA

results.notes:
On forest floor/litter in an Eastern hemlock-dominated mixed forest stand.
Spores subglobose, amyloid, 7-8 × 6-7 uM with ornamentation up to 1.5 uM consisting of isolated warts to bold ridges. Dermatocystidia present in the cap cuticle, 2- to 4-septate (mostly 3-septate), 90-105 uM long.
A Blast search of the rRNA-ITS region in GenBank places this collection at 97% identity or better in a group of sequences identified as Russula emetica, R. nana, R. betularum and R. bicolor – the Emeticinae group in Miller & Buyck (2002). It is more than 99.5% identical to four sequences in GenBank identified as Russula subemetica and 98.9% identical another MO collection (#316195) identified as Russula sp.
I’ve chosen not to call this Russula subemetica because I suspect this to be a misapplied name. R. subemetica was described by Schulzer, S. in 1880 in Micologische Beitrge. V. Verhandlungen der Zoologisch-Botanischen Gesellschaft Wien. 30:487-498. I could find almost no reference to this species in the European literature, save a checklist of Agaricales from Croatia (Mycotaxon 88: 279-314) where it is referred to a section on “Excluded Records” as “Russula subemetica Schulzer = ?”.
As far as I can tell, use of this name for a North American taxon can be traced to a GenBank sequence (KX389129) identified as R. subemetica. However further research shows that this sequence was obtained from a mycorrhizal root tip and was apparently identified as this species based upon a Blast search in GenBank. I can find no GenBank record for R. subemetica that pre-dates the submission of KX389129 so how the author arrived at this identification is unknown, and since the identifier has died there is no way to find out. All I can say is that if there was a sequence in GenBank identified as R. subemetica that predates KX389129, it is not longer available. Regardless, no sporcarp of Schulzer’s concept of R. subemetica was examined by the author of KX389129 as the ID was based upon a mycorrhizal root tip sequence. The remaining GenBank identifications as R. subemetica post-date KX389129 and have likely propagated the KX389129 ID.

notes_fields.Substrate: This was found on a decaying log in clusters. It was a fallen log with leaves all over it. The log was found near a living tree as well. It was also found on a couple of nearby pieces of fallen bark/logs.
notes_fields.Habitat: It seems to grow in clusters around the log, some were found under (closer to the ground) and others were found on the top facing the sun. The clusters ranges from about 1-4cm in length. Some patches were slightly larger or smaller.

results.notes: The fungus looks to be apothecia like, forming a cup structure when looked at very closely. It is white and some of the apothecia look to have a stem or attachment to the bark itself. The apothecia were very small (maybe 1mm at most) and looked almost mold like when it was first found.
results.location_name: Bill's Woods, UW-Madison Lakeshore Nature Preserve, Madison, Wisconsin, USA

notes_fields.Location: Old Orchard Field, UW Madison Lakeshore Nature Preserve
notes_fields.Substrate: This was found on a fallen tree that was covered in moss. There was some clustered growth, but others grew alone.
notes_fields.Habitat: The location is near an area that gets burned regularly. There are many fallen trees and branches all throughout this area. Others of the same species were found on the same tree as well.

results.notes: The whole fungus was about 6cm in length. It was mostly white on the top surface, having slightly uneven edges. It was very hard to the touch. The underside looked to have gills that are very large and noticeable. They were spaced out slightly. the bottom was also mostly white, but a little yellow/dirtier than the top surface had looked like.
results.location_name: Old Orchard Field, UW-Madison Lakeshore Nature Preserve, Madison, Wisconsin, USA

notes_fields.Location: Bills Woods, UW Madison Lakeshore Nature Preserve
notes_fields.Substrate: This mushroom was found on top of a fallen log. The area was mostly shaded and had many fallen trees surrounding it.
notes_fields.Habitat: This was the only mushroom on the log, no other of the same kind was found in the immediate area around it. It was firm to the touch, but was easily breakable and not brittle.

results.notes: The mushroom was about 3cm wide. It was a chocolate brown on the cap surface and was almost folding in on itself. The undersurface was much lighter, almost white. It had light brown speckles on it and the rim of the cap was more black. The underside curved up as well, so you can see both at the same time. There does not seem to be any stem, but rather growth directly from the log. If there was a stem present, it was too small to observe.
results.location_name: Bill's Woods, UW-Madison Lakeshore Nature Preserve, Madison, Wisconsin, USA

results.notes:
At least 15 years ago I planted material from a morel grow kit onto my property. I split the contents between three different areas, each with an old (healthy) apple tree. Last year was the first time a morel has ever appeared in any of these spots obs 407533 same location as this present observation, about 4 feet away. Over the years I have tossed morel trimmings and dumped water used to clean trays form my dehydrator into this area. The fruit body seen here (as well as 407533) does not look like any of our native PA species. 15 years seems like a long time for sclerotia to persist. I wonder if the planted Morchella has become naturalized? Possibly forming an association with the apple tree?

I wanted to wait longer than 5 days to harvest this. But a windy/chilly night seemed like a threat. So I plucked it. Just barely mature enough to drop a few spores. I also found some spores via a smash mount of hymenium. All spores observed were in the range 17-23 × 11-14. This is too small for M. angusticeps and way too small for M. snyderi. Range is a good match for M. importuna. Some aspects of this fruit body seem to not be a particularly good match for M. importuna; the relatively stout stature and lack of “ladder-like” cross-ridges. Perhaps this is due to prevailing atmospheric conditions (range in temperature/humidity) different from what is typical where M. importuna is usually found. If M. importuna is the correct ID then it is interesting to me that a presumably saprobic fungus would survive in an alien environment apparently devoid of its favored nutrient source (spread wood chips) while not producing fruit bodies (until after 15 years). It is my understanding that some morel grow kits are seeded with sclerotia. Could a sclerotium remain in-situ for 15 years? Or has this fungus formed an association with something where it was planted (presumably with the large healthy apple tree)?
When this ITS sequence first became available there were BLAST matches with each of M. laurentiana and M. eohespera. The edited version of the sequence is now seen to match multiple representatives of M. eohespera, and M. laurentiana does not appear. Other matches include names representing taxa from section Distantes (angusticeps, importuna, etc…). I think these names were likely assigned to the given sequences prior to the availability of the names “laurentiana” or “eohespera.”

results.notes:
On rotting wood on mossy forest floor in an Eastern hemlock-dominated mixed forest stand.
Cap reddening to blackening in 3% KOH. Remnants of a fibrillose veil on young, dried specimens. Spores brown, ellipsoid slightly flattened on one side, 8.5-9.5 × 4.5-5.5 uM. Slightly dextrinoid in Melzers. Cheilocystidia distinctly capitate.
A Blast search of GenBank revealed multiple sequences that were identified by the depositers as G. penetrans or G. hybridus with >99% similarity to this collection, although there were sequences identified as G. penetrans with as little as 95% similarity to this sequence, suggesting that species concepts are unclear. Hesler (1969) Mycol. Memoir #3 reserved the name G. hybridus for a European species and did not see NA material that he would refer to this species. Some authors (e.g. Holec J. 2005) consider G. hybridus a synonym of G. penetrans (which seems supported by the Blast results) but others advocate keeping G. hybridus, G. penetrans and G. sapineus as separate species. More work needs to be done.

Pileus (2 cm diameter, 0,9cm height) hemispheric, dry surface probably hygrophnous, greyish colored more brown at the center, excedent margin.
Gills adnate black motted with white edge. Spore print black
Stipe (5 cm height, 0,3 cm wide) purinose at the apex, grey color more brownish at the base. Darkening to brown when damaged.
No bruise blue reaction observed.
results.location_name: Crdoba, Spain

results.notes:
Growing on urban park, caespitosa.
Pileus (1,1 to 1,3 cm diameter, 0,3 to 0,65 cm height) plano convex, dry surface slightly hygrophnous, greyish-brown colored with redish tones, excedent margin.
Gills adnate black motted with white edge. Spore print black
Stipe (6 to 6,7 cm height, 0,2 cm wide) purinose at the apex, grey color with redish tones more brownish at the base. Darkening to brown when damaged.
No bruise blue reaction observed.
results.location_name: Crdoba, Spain

results.notes:
Growing on urban park, growing near each other.
Pileus (0,5 to 0,9 cm diameter, 0,5 to 0,9cm height) campanulate with strange margin nearly closed to the stipe, dry surface slightly hygrophnous, yellow-brown colored to cheasnut brown, largely excedent margin.
Gills adnate gray not motted with white edge. Unable to get spore print
Stipe (4,6 cm height, 0,3 cm wide) purinose at the apex, creamy color brownish at the base.
No bruise blue reaction observed.
The first look was like a type of Conocybe, but the stipe is sturdy and resistent. For the gills color can be a Panaeolus or even a Psilocybe or other genera.
It can look like a strange form of Psilocybe semilanceata, but very rare to find growing on spring in Crdoba.
results.location_name: Crdoba, Spain

results.notes:
Neocudoniella radicella 50225
Apothcie

0,2-2,5 mm de diam., turbine enroule, stipite, marge bien dlimite

Hymnophore

blanc crmeux, translucide

Pied

2-4 × 0,15-0,25 mm, attnu vers la base, concolore l’hymnophore, translucide

Asques

largis jusqu’ 2 m de diam. vers l’apex, 8 spores bisries, avec pore apical modrment amylode, surtout aprs prtraitement au KOH, 33-50 × 3,5-5,2 m

Paraphyses

disperses, filiformes, ne dpassant pas les asques

Spores

troitement ellipsodes, hyalines, 5-9 × 1,5-2,2 m

Excipulum

de deux types :

a) mdulla en textura intricata
b) excipulum ectal form de cellules rectangulaire ascendantes

cologie

sur fines racines d’pinettes parmi les sphaignes

Comestibilit

non comestible

Remarques

N. albiceps diffre par ses apothcies roses, brunes tan, mais parfois blanc translucide, glatineuses, ses spores lgrement plus larges, 5-8 × 2-3 m, et sa pousse sur bois pourri.
Pour comparaison, voir les descriptions de Cudoniella clavus et Roseodiscus subcarneus.

*Rfrences**

Ascomycete Fungi of North America. A Mushrooms reference guide, 2014. Beug. M.W., Bessette, A.E. & Bessette, A.R.

Adaptation

Roland Labb, fvrier 2016.

notes_fields.Substrate: This was found on a decaying log after some of the bark was pulled back. This was a large fallen tree that was decaying.
notes_fields.Habitat: It seemed to grow very tightly to the log itself. There were clusters of the yellow mold and some was found in a smaller area. It was growing in a hyphae-like formation.

results.notes: This was a bright yellow mold that was about 3cm wide in its largest cluster on the tree. The mold itself seemed to go within the tree as well, where some of the “hyphae” go deeper into the wood and others do not. There were no fruiting bodies present on the mold.

notes_fields.Substrate: This fungus was found on a decaying log. It was pretty dry to the touch.
notes_fields.Habitat: This was found growing all along the fallen log. It formed these clusters and lacked a stem. It was a yellowish white color and did not have a regular growth it seemed liked. They may have coalesced over time. Most likely a crust type fungus.

results.notes: The individual clusters were about 2-3cm in width. They grew in smaller formations that formed a general cluster. These were found in different spots along this log. There did not seem to be any apothecial or basidium growth. The clusters were lumpy and had some more circular parts to it.

results.notes:
Neodasyscypha cerina – 50705
Rcolt par J. Cimon

Substrat *: bois pourri de feuillu (htre?)

Apothcie *jusqu 0,48 mm de hauteur totale x 0,43 mm de diam., urcole, courtement stipite

Hymnophore * jaune

Face externe fortement pubescente et jaune olivtre lorsque ferme, marge enroule

Stipe jusqu 0,24 mm de hauteur, court, noir

Asques subcylindriques, 8 spores souvent bisries au dbut, puis emmles au tiers suprieur, paroi mince, hyalins, avec pore apical amylode et contenu lgrement dextrinode dans Lugol, 34-46,4 × 4- 7,4 m

Paraphyses cylindriques, sublancoles, effiles lapex, septes, contenu huileux, avec nombreuses fines guttules jauntres, 33,7-46,4 × 1,7-2,6 m, dpassant les asques de 5-7 m

Spores oblongues subfusiformes, lisses, non septes ni guttules, hyalines, 4,3-5,9 × 1,5-2,6 m

Excipulum** en textura porrecta

Poils externes* cylindriques, paroi +ou- paissie, multisepts, brun olivac, plus ples vers l’apex, densment couverts de granules ocres bruns, jusqu 103 × 4 m

Granules *jusqu 2,2 m de hauteur par jusqu 1,7 m de diam.

NB. D la consistance fermement glifie du sous hymnium, la prsence de crochets basaux na pu tre confirme

Description: J. Labrecque

tude microscopique et microphotographie: J. Labrecque

Recherche et revision de texte: R. Labb

Identification: J. Cimon

notes_fields.Habitat: Deciduous forest with scattered conifers. Found in Madison, Wisconsin. A damp environment with the beginning growth of ephemerals and mosses. Closer to Lake Mendota, an inland lake, than other areas of Lakeshore Nature Preserve.
notes_fields.Substrate: The sample was found growing in a decaying tree log that seems to have been decaying for >one year. Scattered along with the log and creeps in a thin, but also a long aggregation of small puffballs.
notes_fields.Location: Caretaker’s Woods, UW-Madison Lakeshore Nature Preserve, Madison, Wisconsin, USA
notes_fields.Special_Features: With yellowish to olive granular inner structure filled with brownish spore dust— seen observed under the microscope. When sliced in half, a veil can be seen and there is a small hallow-like area where the gills are formed. This contrasts with some puffball mushrooms that are solid. A rhizoidal thread also observed.

results.notes: This sample was found in early spring, so it is likely that this is a fungi that has lasted over the winter, and its projectile spores will likely bare this years population.
results.location_name: Caretaker's Woods, UW-Madison Lakeshore Nature Preserve, Madison, Wisconsin, USA

notes_fields.Habitat: Deciduous forest with scattered conifers. Found in Madison, Wisconsin. A damp environment with the beginning growth of ephemerals and mosses. Closer to Lake Mendota, an inland lake, than other areas of Lakeshore Nature Preserve.
notes_fields.Substrate: Sample was found on the underside of a decaying log that was covered in leaves. This was the only colony found on the log, perhaps it’s just beginning its growth for the season.
notes_fields.Location: Caretakers Woods, UW-Madison Lakeshore Nature Preserve, Madison, Wisconsin, USA
notes_fields.Special_Features: Very hard to see without being very observant and the use of a hand lens. Fungi appears to be a reddish-brown producing many stalks producing many heads— resulting in the cluster-like morphology displayed below.

notes_fields.Substrate: Growing on old, possibly burnt log surrounded by various mosses and other species of slime molds.
notes_fields.Setting: Habitat was well off the trail in a mixed forest setting. Patch it was found in was brushy and it sat right in between a mixture of spring ephemerals and downed branches.
notes_fields.Morphology: Three small, distinct patches in close proximity to each other. While other slime mold took up a lot of space on the log, this species was limited to its one specific part of the log. Dark red fruiting bodies formed in dense clumps on on stalk. A more orangey flesh appeared to be hanging out of some of the open cavities of the fruiting bodies.

notes_fields.Substrate: Found on a moist, well-decayed piece of log that appeared to have broken off of rest of fallen tree. Log had plenty of moss covering it and was covered in small holes, perhaps from boring insects. The exact part of the log that the basidiocarps were emerging from was noticeably darker than the rest of the log, and felt wet to the touch.
notes_fields.Setting: Off the path in a mixed forest, specifically underneath a couple coniferous trees. Found in close proximity to Urnula craterium.
notes_fields.Morphology: Found in a small cluster of three fruiting bodies in close proximity to eachother. External head of basidiocarp was incredibly smooth. Stipes were mostly a light brown with some darker brown splotches. Stipe and basidium both appeared very fresh and felt moist. Spore print was a rusty brown.

notes_fields.Substrate: Found on dead but standing hardwood tree. Wood was beggining to decompose but appeared fairly dry. Bark around the area where fungus was found had begun to peel away from tree.
notes_fields.Setting: Found in a predominantly deciduous stand in a mixed forest just off of a walking path. Fairly close proximity to a large lake.
notes_fields.Morphology: Single pileus growing alone without any visible stipe. Exterior (top) of cap was extremely hard and almost wood-like. Top of cap also had a growth ring type appearance. I at first thought it was Ganoderma applanatum, as the bottom of the pileus was also white. However, upon scratching the bottom I realized it did not scratch brown, instead staying completely white. In addition, cap was much less symmetric than Ganoderma, and it appeared that a hoof type formation had begun.

results.notes:
Macro: Thallus surface a matte light brown to medium brown. Marginal lobes more or less appressed to substrate, generally convex but not inflated, and tending to fan out at tips. Apothecia: smaller, younger aps borwnish-red, immersed, larger, older aps becoming sessile. Aps concave to plane. Some aps growing into each other. Thallus lobe rims and areas around pycnidia often white. Fanned out thallus lobe tips 1-1.5 mm diameter. Largest individual aps observed ~1mm diam. Micro: cortex appears paraplectenchymatous. Algae in scattered bunches below cortex. Upper layer of cortex brown, epinecral layer present on top of that. Apothecia with reddish-brown epihymenium. Paraphyses appear to be submoniliform. Algae present below hypothecium.

Spores: couldn’t find enough for consistent measurements, same with asci.

Chemistry: Cortex and medulla both K+ yellow to red (norstictic acid)
